intro: Lagochilus kschtutensis, commonly known as the Armenian rock hyssop, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Armenia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its small, tubular flowers are usually purple or blue, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
